review_blob: Delicious and satisfying contender to Hoynes Dark Matter. Aroma is akin to a Russian Imperial Stout - burnt and slightly bittered with lots of roasted malt. Appearance is again similar to a RIS...small brownish head, beautiful black colour. Satisfying and rich flavor of roasted malt, black licorice, and a slight hop bite. Tastes "cold" and and a bit harsh if that makes sense, but once sipped it is a warming brew. Leaves a lingering licorice-esque bitterness that is exceedingly pleasant. Wonderful brew, would almost take it over Dark Matter.

Nothing bad, but to me, its odd for a marzen. The marzens I had abroad in Austria tasted much different than this, and looked it too.

Appearance is oddly deep copper, with an attractive fluffy white head. Aroma is slightly spicy with a tiny hint of hops. Taste is spicy, slightly floral with a nice bitter bite and a stronger hop presence than most Germanic beers Ive had. Palate has a lingering hop bitterness without being offensive. Overall, not bad but odd to me.

Nothing amazing, but not bad either. A decent enough brew.

Pour results in minimal head. Appearance is a soft copper colour, similar to an Old Speckled Hen. Aroma is decidedly underwhelming - very little going on here, kind of smells like a brown ale. Taste is far more similar to a brown ale or red ale than an ESB...whereas ESBs and other English Bitters have a floral, spicy character, this one tastes fairly malty and nutty, yet muted. Palate is nothing much to speak of, not much lingering flavor. Overall, its good enough, but nothing to write home about.
beer_name: Duchy Originals Organic Old Ruby Ale 1905

review_blob:
I am not typically a wheat ale kind of guy, but this is quite decent. Keep in mind, Im not an aficionado when it comes to this style.

Appearance is cloudy, golden, typical of a wheat beer. Aroma is also tangy and inviting, floral and mild but expected for the style. Flavor is very good, nothing odd for a wheat beer, but refreshing and non-offensive while still being distinct. Palate is pleasant with no lingering aftertastes. Overall, a good introductory beer for this particular style.
beer_name: Minhas Lazy Mutt Alberta Wheat Ale

review_blob:
An interesting beer, this one. For some reason Im reminded of Guinness Extra Stout or a porter of some kind...

Appearance is a very dark brown with a decent head. Aroma is not very enticing to me - quite hopped and sharp. Taste, however is full-flavored and hearty - a solid dose of hop bitterness mixed with a deep roasted malt flavor and hints of licorice. A bit too much of a hop punch for me, but for someone who wants to try Russian stouts and the darker porters but is a bit scared too, this is a good choice. Palate is lingering, bitter, smoky and pungent.

Overall, it tastes nothing like other Brown Ales such as the famous Newcastle Brown, but rather more like a light version of a Russian Imperial Stout. Worth a shot for sure.

Here, in my opinion, we have a great example of a hoppier-tasting beer done right. I figured this as a pale ale, but apparently its an ESB? Seems to be not nearly as complex as an ESB but okay...

Appearance is amber/light burnt orange with a slightly puffy head. Aroma is extremely pleasant, like sweet rain with a slight hop scent. Flavor is well-done for a hoppier beer: a good dose of bitterness that is not offensive like many "craft" IPAs, with a solid malt foundation and a hint of the floral/spicy character of the English Bitter style. Palate is pleasantly dry, with a sharp bitter taste that doesnt overstay its welcome. 

Overall, a very decent hoppy beer, though for my tastes, its still a little too hoppy. If you like this one, give Wychwood Brewerys Goliath a try.

I was excited to try this one, as I am enjoying my exploration of the world of local porters. Unfortunately, this one really turned out to be a disappointment.

Unlike any porter Ive come across, this one pours a thin dark brown/barely black with a small head. Quite clear and see through for a beer of this type. Aroma is a turn-off right away, with a pungent whiff of hops coming through; before I even had my first sip, I was rolling my eyes internally at the state of the hop-crazed beer culture of the Pacific Northwest.

Flavor was distinctly unlike other porters I have had. Whereas Hoynes Dark Matter has a crisp and satisfying taste of milk chocolate and roasted malt and Okanagan Springs Porter is a decidedly rich and slightly licorice-flavored specimen, this one cuts across the tongue with a flavor of piney hops mixed with the taste of stale coffee grinds. Simply put, it was awful. The hops nearly dominate the flavor of this beer.

Palate-wise, the beer is thin and somewhat watery, and leaves an aftertaste in ones mouth akin to if one had sucked on a bar of soap for about a half an hour.

Unless you love IPAs and want to pretend to like dark beer too, avoid this one.

Hahaha...well, I suppose I could try and review this one. Problem is, there is not much if anything to review.

Aroma? What aroma? Maybe a tiny, microscopic hint of cardboard or grain. Appearance is watery and pee-yellow, with minimal head. Almost looks like a faint white wine. Taste is minimal at the very best - slight hint of wet cardboard and rice sort of present. Palate is watery, thin, highly-carbonated. Pure garbage...makes Lucky Lager look almost half-decent, and Bud Light actually seem full-flavoured. Hilarious.

Not a bad beer. However, in my opinion, the aroma is terrible: smells medicinal, not enticing at all. Yuck.

That said, the flavor is quite good. Not as bitter as most German beers (esp. Bitburger and Tuborg Pilsner), this one offers a gentler bite with a good dose of hearty Carlsberg-esque hay and grain flavor. Full-flavored and delicious for a blonde beer. Appearance is nice too - grandiose head, rich gold colour. Palate is smooth, with lingering bitterness.

If you can get past the

Good for what it is, this style of stout is still a wee bit heavy for me. Nonetheless, Stoutnik is a great entry level beer for those interested in exploring the foreboding russian imperial stout style. 

Black as an endless abyss, minimal dark tan head. Aroma is sweetish with some milk chocolate, coffee and licorice scents thrown in. Taste is surprisingly gentle for this kind of stout; neither oily nor overly-molasses flavored, nor with the hop punch of Old Rasputin or Narwhal. Predominant milk chocolate and roasted barley flavor, with a licorice bite afterwards. 

If youre new to this style, give this one a whirl and then go on to deeper and darker things. If youre local, the best way I could describe this is think Dark Matter x 2. Decent and forgiving for the russian style of stout.

Pipers Pale Ale took me some time to get into, but as I have opened up a little to hoppier beers, it has grown on me. 

Pours a light copper orange colour, one-finger head that recedes pretty quickly. Aroma is piney, slightly deceptive in that it smells like its going to be nastier than it actually is. Taste is crisp and pleasant, with an ample hop bite that does not overpower. Lingering bitterness on the palate. In comparison to other local beers of the same type, it stands between Phillips Blue Buck and Okanagan Spring Pale Ale in terms of quality; not as hoppy as Blue Buck (which is a good thing given that Phillips always overdoes it on the hops) but not as fresh-tasting as OS Pale Ale. 

Overall, a good choice for the style, and representative of the quality of Vancouver Island Brewerys tasteful restraint in their beer styles.
UPDATED: AUG 15, 2014

Very good lager, extremely impressed - enjoy this one much more than the "oak-aged" beers Innis and Gunn is known for.

Aroma is slightly piney without being off-putting, crisp and clear. The beer smells exceedingly fresh. Appearance, for a lager, is a rich gold - very attractive. Taste is complex (especially for a lager) - a mix of malt, oat-derived smoothness, hint of wheat tang and a solid yet not overpowering hop bite. Palate is smooth, refreshing, with a lingering bitterness. Overall, a fantastic choice, especially for the style. Really enjoyed this one.

An okay beer, not as good as I had hoped it would be. Still, not a bad lager by any means. Aroma is where it suffers, with it giving off a bit of sweet corn. Appearance is a pale yellow, much like a Budweiser or Kokanee. Taste is decent for a lager - similar to most lagers but with a slight bit of peppery hop bitterness at the end and a sweetness in the initial taste. Overall its nothing to write home about, but I dont mind it at all for what it is. Decent enough.

Complete garbage that gets by purely on marketing it as some kind of sign that one is an "islander" (Vancouver Islander, that is). 

Aroma? What aroma? Theres simply nothing there - air tinged with a hint of grain. Appearance is about the same as a Budweiser or any other macro lager - pale yellow and not much else. Taste is minimal, like club soda with essence of beer. Palate is faintly metallic, lifeless wisps of nothing.

Overall, I cannot understand why on earth this beer is popular, other than as a "camping beer". Even then, theres a lot better choices out there.

For what it is, its fantastic. But even though I like dark beers, this one is just too dark. 

Aroma is pungent, strong, piercing. Appearance is blacker than pitch - this is something you pave roads with; head is khaki-coloured. No light shines through this thing - this is pure pitch darkness.

Taste is overwhelmingly powerful, a full-assault on the senses. A tiny sweetness tries to sneak through the ridiculously roasted malt flavor. Lots of coffee, chocolate, bit of ash. This is heavy, heavy stuff. 

At colder temperatures, its palatable, and not even bad, despite the fact that Im a dry stout guy, not an imperial stout one. For what it is, its grand...just too much for me.

From Hell. 

This makes most IPAs look like light lagers. Weighing in at a hefty 8.5% abv, Amnesiac is a pure punch in the mouth. Aroma is straight-up pine and lemon furniture cleaner. Appearance is a cloudy orange. Taste is absolutely foul - piercing pine oil, boatloads of citrus peel, bowlful of potpourri. Leaves a rank, lingering bitterness in the mouth. 

Even IPA fans might have trouble stomaching this nasty hop-laden trip.

Nothing wrong with this beer really. Labeled as an "Irish-Style Ale", I assume this is kind of a Canadian take on Smithwicks. 

Aroma is malt, nuts, cereal - no trace of hops. Appearance is an attractive deep amber, nice head that unfortunately dissipates quickly. Taste is nice and malty, slight bitterness in the finish. Clean and smooth, but the flavor should be deeper.

Overall, a fine choice.

First had some on the streets of Vienna - not bad. Drinking this export version of Gosser is better than I remember. Typical-looking lager. Like all Austrian beers, I find that there is a certain German-esque bitterness present, but much lighter. Aroma is pleasant, sweet and fresh. 

Flavor is mildly sweet with a slight bitterness - some corn, faint hops. Palate is pleasant - carbonation is not over-powering, lingering light bitterness. Overall, nothing exactly special, but a decent beer all around.

My wife calls it "ghost beer." 

Honestly, theres really nothing to talk about here. Aroma is tap water with a faint hint of malt. Appearance is kind of like the colour of urine after drinking a decent amount of water, but no so much that the urine comes out clear. Something like that.

Taste? What taste? Flavor is akin to beer-flavored club soda. I suppose this is refreshing if youre nineteen and camping on the lake in the summer heat? Its not terrible so much as non-existent.

Not a bad English bitter at all. Pours like a Kilkenny, super creamy head. Golden-orange in colour. Aroma is slightly sweet, bit of malt. Taste is slightly bitter, some honey, hint of that ESB herbal taste, somewhat sweet. Goes down easier than most beers - incredibly smooth, friendly, and with almost zero cabonation. 

Overall, a good choice. Not as punishing or herbalish as other bitters, comparable to Caffreys or Kilkenny cream ales.

Typical Phillips brew - TONS of hops and little else. The funny thing is that this is supposed to be sort of an IPA-light...

Oddly enough, its not as bad as I thought it would be, but its still damn hoppy.  Aroma is strong of pine and citrus, quite piercing. Taste is sharp, distinct, cutting, punchy - all pine, grapefruit, and bitterness. Lingering aftertaste.

Overall, not as wretched as other IPAs - in fact, I could handle this one if I had to. I even came around to Blue Buck, which to me is pretty hoppy in itself for a non-IPA. But still, too hoppy for me. I imagine IPA lovers who want a beer they can slam down with ease might enjoy this though.

Just okay...I think they changed something in the brewing process awhile ago, because its much better than it used to be. Back in the day, it tasted like licking dirty nickels off the pavement with an aftertaste of Highliner Fish Sticks. Now, its a bit better.

Pours pale yellow, some foam that goes away quickly. Aroma is faint - bits of grain and little else. Taste is slightly bitter, grainy, faint. Lots of carbonation, strangely sourish/bitter aftertaste. 

Still not a very good beer - would take Kokanee or Budweiser over it normally.
UPDATED: AUG 14, 2014

Really decent, flavorful scotch ale. Looks like a Newcastle Brown Ale. Aroma is slightly sour, very malty, lots of toast. Good flavor - nutty, some brown sugar, heavy malt, with a little bit of sweetness reminiscent of something like Gulden Draak (though nearly as sweet). Palate is great - low carbonation, nice and smooth. Worth trying.
beer_name: Russell A Wee Angry Scotch Ale

review_blob: Smooth pilsner offering from Iceland. Pours standard yellow, nice little foamy head on it. Aroma is a little citrus, quite metallic, lots of hay, cereal. Delicious flavor that hits with a punch of pilser-esque bitterness and hay before receding rapidly with a clean metallic zip. Ultra-smooth like a Tiger or an Original 16 Pale Ale. Not bad at all.

Not bad - cheaper than the macro brews of the same type, and brewed like a craft beer. It shows.

Pours standard for a lager. Aroma is reminiscent of a German-style pilsner - locally speaking, the aroma is similar to a lighter version of Okanagan Springs 1516. Flavor is full, good tangy malt, low-hop presence. Pleasantly carbonated. Its good, but ironically with beers of this style, I sometimes prefer something I little less full-flavored.

Just ok...but for me to say that about anything even remotely connected to Phillips Brewery is something - just not a fan.

Slipstream, it seems, is one of the few more malty offerings by a brewery known chiefly for cramming as much hops as is humanly possible into almost every beer they brew. 

Pours a light reddish-brown, not much head on it. Aroma is quite faint - mostly bread. It tastes like they desperately wanted to stuff hops into it, but held back - it has that slight hint of hops to it, but thankfully not to much. Taste is mostly biscuit, bread, with some caramel. Not too bad. Overly-carbonated, but a decent lingering flavor. 

I would drink it again, oddly enough - its not so bad.
beer_name: Phillips Slipstream Cream Ale (aka Draught Dodger 2008)

review_blob: Not bad, but I prefer Duvel to this. Typically complex in the extreme as most Belgian beers tend to be, Delirium pours a rich golden colour with possibly the most majestic and everlasting head I have ever seen. Aroma is similar to a wheat beer like Hoegaarden - floral, pungent, and spicy. Heavy flavors of malt, banana, and sweet spice. Aftertaste has a slight hoppy bite. Heavy cabonaton. Its a quality beer, but like I said, I prefer Duvel still.

This ones for stout lovers ONLY - if you dont dig dark beer, then high-tail it from this beast. 

Pours black as pitch, brownish head that is quite minimal. Aroma is quite hoppy smelling for a stout. Taste is powerful, heavy-duty: bitter, slightly peppery, brutal malt presence, with a bit of a hop bite. Warming alcoholic finish that is exceedingly pleasant. For stout-lovers who are looking for something extra heavy without being like medicinal syrup, this is the ticket.
beer_name: North Coast Old Rasputin Russian Imperial Stout

review_blob:
Something I look forward to every year. Apparently this is simply Hermanns Dark Lager aged longer, etc. What a difference this makes. I love Hermanns, its a smooth and delicious black ale style of beer, but this tops the cake. 

Aroma sucks - lets be honest. Its alcoholic brown sugar. But the taste is incredible, mind-blowing. Hint of chocolate, some caramel, with lots of sweet brown sugar and malt absolutely bombard the tastebuds. Smooth, not overly-carbonated. Packs a massive punch - be careful, its 9.5%. 

A delicious dark beer, like a porter without the licorice flavor and more brown sugar. A beautiful drink, goes down far too easy. Warming, welcoming, damn fine.

Not that I was expecting much, but this is disappointing. Advertised as though Budweiser just discovered the art of brewing beer, this really just tastes like a regular Bud with a little more pronounced flavor. The problem is, the pronounced flavor is not very good at all. Strong alcohol presence makes it taste more like an 8% abv beer than a 6%. Aroma is stunted and off-putting, smelling like malt liquor. Appearance is enticing with its amber/caramel colour, but the taste is not very good at all - alcoholic sweetness mixes with all the flavors of a standard Budweiser lager, but the alcohol masks the flavor of anything remotely good about this beer. Overall, I FAR prefer regular Budweiser to this.

Pours a golden yellow, lacklustre head for a pilsner. Fresh, sweet-ish aroma. Flavor has a slight citrus tang to it, complete with a grainy bitter bite. Aftertaste is a lingering and mild bitterness. High carbonation.

Decent enough pilsner, lacks the intense bite of a Bitburger or Tucher, but still has a good Germanic bitter punch to it.

Normally, I have not liked pumpkin ales very much - ironic, considering I love darker ales and that the Fall is my favorite season. 

Pumpkineater is literally like drinking pumpkin pie. Appearance is a rusty reddish-brown, not much head. The aroma is fresh pumpkin pie, clove, nutmeg, cinnamon. Flavor is rich pumpkin pie, with a malty bitterness reminiscent of the Germanic pilseners. Not overly carbonated, nice and smooth. A wonderful choice for having by the fire on a cold autumn day.
beer_name: Howe Sound Pumpkineater Imperial Pumpkin Ale

review_blob: UPDATED: JAN 22, 2014

A delicious treat for dark beer fans. This particular concoction combines the smoothness of Swans Oatmeal Stout with a sweet coconut infusion of flavor. It works.

Aroma is enticing - malty with sweet coconut. Appearance is enticing, but no creamy head like with most other stouts (though technically this is a porter), so thats definitely disappointing. Otherwise, flavor is rich and tasty, like a candy stout. Coconut flavor is pronounced but not overpowering, mixes beautifully with the malty flavor. This porter feels thin in the end, much like an Irish dry stout - in my books, this is a good thing (nothing worse than a stout or porter so dark that you have to chew it down). Overall, a great treat for the dark beer lover, worth a try...or two...or three...

Very interesting...I may dislike the hoppy beers and all, but this takes anti-hops to a whole new level. Theres no hops at all in this thing. 

Interesting flavor, comparable to some meads Ive had. Honey-ish flavor, almost reminiscent of a sweet soda pop. No bitterness, just a sort of honey-like flavor. Light coppery colour. If youre looking for something new and different, give it a whirl.
beer_name: Saltspring Spring Fever Gruit Ancient Ale

review_blob: I was tipped-off to this one, but ended up underwhelmed. Sampled at Great Canadian Beer Fest. Aroma was ok, appearance was dark brown. I was expecting a rich maple and malt flavor, but was met instead with a disappointing porter that was more like an average brown ale. Slight maple flavour is an understatement - tasting the maple in this drink is like finding a needle in a haystack. Ends up an average brown ale in flavor. Disappointed.

Delicious pale ale from Okanagan Spring Brewery. Aroma is not indicative of the flavor to me - smells like just another hoppy beer that I assumed at first that I wouldnt like. Taste is delicious however - fresh, crisp, a slight hop snap of pine and citrus meets a hearty malt presence. Slightly bitter aftertaste that pleasantly lingers. 
Overall, an excellent choice for an easy-drinking beer that still packs some incredible flavor.

Very good beer - had my first sip of it in Barcelona in a chalice of sorts. 

In Barcelona, I noticed it was slightly different than the cans of it I have picked up in Canada. In Spain, it was amber in colour, but in Canada it is not much different in appearance than most lagers, being a pale yellow. Aroma is a little sweet, flavor is slightly honeyed so that the beer comes off similar to Granville Islands light and crisp Cypress Honey Lager. Ironically, there is no honey in the brew at all, so this is quite interesting to me. 

Overall, a pleasant lager - well done.
UPDATED: SEP 19, 2013

Ok...if the more common stouts out there seem like Bud Light to you, then give this behemoth a whirl. Though still not as dark or chewy as St. Ambroise Oatmeal Stout for example, this imperial licorice stout is absolutely savage in its heaviness. Pours black with a brown foamy head, aroma is intense licorice and anise. Though the palate is lighter than I thought (not necessarily oily/chewy), its a heavy brew. Taste is akin to sweet licorice cigar, lots of anise aftertaste. For what it is, its good. Just not something I would want to drink often, or even a lot of.
beer_name: Howe Sound Megadestroyer Imperial Licorice Stout

review_blob:
Seemed to me to be false advertising with this one - this tastes like no porter or stout Ive ever had. 

Like an Innis and Gunn gone off, this pseudo-porter is neither black, nor good. Kind of like a dark woody brown in colour, seems thin. Aroma is woody, with hints of vanilla and ash. Tastes like a bad scotch mixed with Buckleys cough syrup. Oily on the tongue. I tried to down the small sample I had at the Great Canadian Beer Festival, but just couldnt finish it. Ended up pouring it out. I suppose if you like your beers to taste like medicine, then go for it. But a porter this isnt. Major disappointment.
beer_name: Paddock Wood Black Friars 17C London Ale (Barrel-Aged & Brett)

review_blob:
YUCK! Normally, Okanagan Springs line of beers are fantastic examples of craft brewing. However, this particular entry is not - I imagine even wheat and fruit beer aficionados will not enjoy this one. 

Smells like sweet apricots, and is inviting. Pours a pale orange colour, almost looks attractive for a beer of its type - the colour seems to be exactly like the colour of a ripe apricots skin. Unfortunately, the taste is awful. Imagine swallowing liquid glycerin soap with apricot flavoring, and youve got a general idea of what this tastes like. Ridiculously sweet, almost sickeningly so - combine that with the wheaty graininess and you have one awful beer.

Avoid.

I love Granville Island - in my opinion, they make some of the tastiest beers in BC. But this particular entry is insulting to Irish beer. Yuck.

No beer in Ireland that I have ever had has the amount of hops that this thing does; on the contrary, Irish beers are known for their maltiness. This tastes like some trendy Phillips beer - jacked up with as much hops as can be stuffed into the bottle, while still looking like a Smithwicks. A terrible beer, nothing like a real Irish red ale.

I heard really good things about this particular brew, and given the fact that I have been exploring the world of English ales as of late, London Pride seemed to be an obvious choice. Certainly, the ratings I have read seem to speak highly of it.

So far, London Pride tastes like a typical example of the style - goes down smooth and easy, but packs a pronounced flavor and snappy bite. Aroma is floral, woodsy, spicy, fruity, but all in a mild-medium sense (in other words, it doesnt smell like a rum-and-raisin doppelmalz or something). Flavor has a mild pepperish bite, a good quantity of hops, with a dose of toffee and malt. I find the taste of this one akin to Old Speckled Hen, which is also a worthy selection. Appearance is light copper/amber. Mild carbonation, bitter aftertaste typical of the style.

Overall, its not the beat-all, end-all of English ales, but it seems to be a good example of this kind of beer. Personally, I prefer Tetleys Smoothflow, but if one wants a bitter with more of a pronounced punch, then London Pride is the way to go.
UPDATED: SEP 15, 2013
beer_name: Great Western Original 16 Canadian Copper Ale

review_blob:
Well...theres really nothing to rate. When my wife and I went to Vegas, this garbage was everywhere. And given the fact that Vegas is hotter than the first three rings of Hell, it was actually nice to get, simply due to its being beer and being cold. 
Other than that, theres nothing to it. Everything is what youd expect - minimal aroma, tastes like club soda with a hint of beer flavoring, but its passable on a brutally hot day. Inexplicable why it sells for any other reason though.
UPDATED: AUG 30, 2013
UPDATED: AUG 30, 2013
